Synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol has gained major research attention because of its wide application in lithium-ion battery and pharmaceutical companies. Current study summarises the catalytic transformation of glycerol-to-glycerol carbonate using MgTiO3 perovskite catalyst. Here,we have reported the synthesis of MgTiO3 catalyst by simple co-precipitation route and investigated the catalytic activity in transesterification of glycerol. The physico-chemical properties of MgTiO3 catalyst was successfully studied by XRD, SEM-EDX, XPS, Raman spectra, BET-surface area and TGA analysis. The designed catalyst possesses high catalytic efficiency and stability in transesterification reaction of glycerol. Depending upon its surface area and basicity many experiments were performed and observed that under optimized condition i.e., 12 wt.% catalyst loading, 6:1 molar ratio of DMC to glycerol, 90 °C and at 180 min highest conversion of glycerol 93% and 88% selectivity of glycerol carbonate was achieved. The reusability study also revealed that MgTiO3 perovskite is highly efficient and stable catalyst to trans esterify glycerol with 88% selectivity towards glycerol carbonate up to sixth cycle. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MgTiO3 perovskite Glycerol carbonate Transesterification Glycerol Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Energy consumption is rapidly increasing over worldwide as a result of technology advancements and human development. Basically, two types of energy sources like fossil fuels, as non-renewable energy and renewable sources like solar, wind, biomass are utilised in industrial, building and transportation sectors tremendously [1–5]. The burning of fossil fuel causes environmental degradation and the production of waste which are main factors for imbalance of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2). As a result, biofuel like biodiesel, bio ethanol, biomethanol are extensively used worldwide to fulfil the energy demand. The enormous production of biodiesel causes large scale accumulation of glycerol as by-product [6,7]. In order to economize the biodiesel production process recent research attention has been focused towards the conversion of glycerol to several value-added product. Glycerol carbonate is one of the value-added product having water solubility and nontoxic properties mostly used in pharmaceuticals, beauty and personal care industries, agricultural industries, building and cement factories as well as lithium-ion batteries [8–11]. Depending upon the types of feed materials glycerol carbonate can be synthesized by various pathways like use of phosgene, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, urea, and dialkyl carbonate etc. [12–14]. The synthetic pathway of glycerol carbonate using phosgene, CO and CO2 has been obsoleted due to unsafe and high toxicity properties of these chemicals. Although the use of CO and CO2 provided relatively high yield but these processes are thermodynamically limited and requires high temperature and pressure [15–20]. Compared to all these process transesterification reaction of glycerol using dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is most promising and facile one. This method is environmental benign and greener for glycerol carbonate synthesis under mild reaction condition. A variety of heterogeneous, homogeneous and enzymatic catalysts have been used for synthesis of glycerol carbonate [21,22]. The enzymatic systems are highly sensitive to poisoning and requires long reaction time. Although homogeneous catalysts like NaOH, K2CO3, etc. shows high catalytic performance but suffered inconvenient separation process [23,24]. In order to overcome all these problems and achieving highest product yield numerous heterogenous catalysts have been explored. Heterogeneous catalysts like KNO3/CaO [25], Mg- Ca [26], NaOH/ γ-Al2O3 [27], Li/ZnO [20], Ca/ZrO2 [28], Ca/La [29], KF/Y-Al2O3 [30], Na modified zeolites [31] are used for synthesis of glycerol carbonate. Diverse application of Ca based mixed catalysts have been used for transesterification of glycerol. The disadvantages of such type of catalytic system includes prolonged reaction time, high reaction temperature, poor reusability, high energy consumption, and use of more than one solvent etc. Few applications of Mg based heterogeneous catalysts in transesterification of glycerol has been reported till date, for example catalysts like Mg-La [11], LiNO3/Mg4AlO5.5 [16], Mg/Zr/Sr [32], Mg/Al [33] mixed oxides and fluorine doped Mg/Al mixed oxides [34]. Although these catalysts have high reactivity, the selectivity towards glycerol carbonate was supressed due to many sides’ reaction like glycidol, glyceryl acid, 1,3-Propanediol etc. formation. Some researchers investigated Mg and Ti mixed oxide catalysts and examined it in different reaction process. Titanium based catalysts have efficient catalytic performance in photocatalysis, thermally stable and high charge separation and acidic properties. Oxides with perovskite structure provides moderate acidity and basicity for synthesis of cyclic carbonate [35–37]. Magnesium titanate (MgTiO3) have been extensively used in ceramic capacitor and resonator due to high thermal stability at high frequencies and low dielectric loss. As the band gap energy of MgTiO3 is up to 3.4–3.7 eV, many researchers have explored this in water splitting reaction and photocatalytic hydrogen production [38]. Titanate having multiple oxidation state exhibits strong acidic properties and activates the carbonyl groups like ketones and aldehydes. On the other hand, titania is considered as most promising supporter and promoter for various base catalysed organic reactions. The insertion of Group IA and IIA metals to titania improves the basicity and structural stability of the catalyst, resulting in improved catalytic activity and reusability. To the best of our knowledge MgTiO3 has not been used in transesterification of glycerol using DMC as solvent. Undoubtedly, Mg based MgTiO3 catalyst is cheaper one and non-toxic by nature. Here we synthesized this perovskite by simple co-precipitation method taking nitrate as source and applied this catalyst for glycerol carbonate synthesis. The catalytic efficiency, stability and reusability were studied in this work and found that catalyst is one of the efficient providing 88% selectivity towards glycerol carbonate and stable up to fifth cycle. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Magnesium nitrate, Mg (NO3)2·6H2O), Titanium nitrate Ti(NO3)4, Ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH), Glycerol, Dimethyl carbonate were purchased from Merck, India and used for the synthesis without purification. The catalytic sample namely MgTiO3 was synthesized via co-precipitation route. Initially 150 mmol of Mg (NO3)2 salt was dissolved in deionized water and then 150 mmol of titanium nitrate solution was prepared separately. The molar ratio of both the metals were kept 1:1 ratio while preparing the solution. The prepared solutions were mixed and stirred at room temperature for 5 h to form homogeneous solution. There was dropwise addition of ammonia solution to the reaction mixture in order to get the precipitate with pH of 10.0. After that the precipitate was washed with excess water and ethanol subsequently and filtered. Then drying was done for 24 h at 120 °C before being calcined for 4 h at 800 °C. The designed mixed oxide catalyst was undergone for several characterizations. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure, orientation and phase of the synthesized catalysts was analysed by Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer with Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation. The sample was characterized in between 10°–90° range with a step size of 0.008° and a scanning rate of 5°per min. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) with a Mettler Toledo 1 instrument was used to investigate the thermal stability of the synthesized catalyst. Physical properties like surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of the catalyst were further investigated using the Micromeritics −2720 volumetric instrument adopting N2 adsorption-desorption technique. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) by Thermo scientific Kα spectrometer with Al Kα radiation was used to determine the binding energy and surface oxidation state of the catalyst. The morphological study and compositional analysis of synthesized catalysts was studied by SEM EDX using Nova instrument with acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The Raman spectra of the sample was recorded on a Horiba JY Lab RAM HR800 Micro-Raman spectrometer equipped with He-Ne laser light source excited by a wave length of 632.8 nm. 2.3 Catalytic reaction/ performance of catalyst The efficacy and stability of synthesized catalyst was investigated in transesterification of glycerol.Around 2 g of glycerol and 5.87 g of DMC was taken in a 250 ml round bottom flask and 100 mg of catalyst was added into the flask. The reaction mixture was heated at 90 °C for 3 h with constant stirring. After that the cooling of product mixture was done, then filtered and the sample was collected to analyse by gas chromatography to confirm the formation of glycerol carbonate as desired product. In this similar way various molar ratios of glycerol to DMC like (gly: DMC:: 1:1, 1:2, 1:3, 1:4 …) with different weight percentage of catalyst like (1, 3, 5, 7, 9 ….) according to wt% glycerol used were taken to trans esterify glycerol. All the products formed in the reaction process were analysed by GC with HP-5MS capillary column (30 m) and the conversion, selectivity and yield of glycerol carbonate were determined using the expressions given below. (1) Glycerol Conversion ( % ) = N o o f m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l r e a c t e d T o t a l n o o f m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l t a k e n × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = N o o f m o l e s o f d e s i r e d p r o d u c t T o t a l n o o f m o l e s o f a l l p r o d u c t s × 100 (3) Yield ( % ) = % glycerol conv × % GLC selectivity 100 3 Results and discussion The thermal stability of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst was analysed through TG analysis for determination of suitable annealing temperature of pure inorganic phases and depicted in Fig. 1 . The thermal decomposition of designed catalyst was associated with three dominant phases. The initial mass loss of the sample occurred between 90 and 150 °C, which might be due to the evaporation of surface water molecules present in the catalyst [39,40]. The disintegration of crystal water molecules or any other organic contaminants present in the sample may have caused the second phase of mass loss, which occurred between 200° and 450 °C. Due to the dissolution of nitrate groups contained in the sample materials, the third phase of mass loss occurred in temperatures ranging from 500° to 700 °C [41,42]. There was no weight loss of the compound above 700 °C, indicating that the MgTiO3 catalyst was completely formed. The crystal structure, phase purity and crystal orientation of designed catalyst was analysed by use of X-ray diffraction technique and represented in Fig. 2 . It is observed that all the diffraction patterns were intense, which indicates that the synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst is purely crystalline with single phase of system. The diffraction peaks were matched with JCPDS file pattern 01–079–0831. Mainly six strongest diffraction peaks at 2θ values 24.29°,38.13°, 48.13°, 53.10°, 56.20°, 63.92° corresponding miller indices values (200), (222), (331), (422), (511), (440) exactly assigned to perovskite MgTiO3 in XRD pattern. All the diffraction peaks possess rhombohedral pattern with space group R-3 and unit cell parameters a = 5.0438A°, and c = 13. 8992A°. Besides these some other diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.27°, 68.17°and 74.38° are consigned to minor secondary phase of TiO2 [43,44]. Using Debye- Scherer's equation, the crystallite size of MgTiO3 catalyst was estimated and determined to be 49 nm. The SEM micrograph of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst calcinated at 700 °C was depicted in Fig. 3 . The particles are round shaped with severe agglomeration. Most of the particles are round shaped and uniformly distributed. The average particle size of MgTiO3 catalyst was found to be 58 nm and due to very high agglomeration the particle size was increased. The lattice spacing of rhombohedral crystal system of MgTiO3 was calculated taking (331) plane and found to be 0.34 nm. The elements present in designed catalyst was studied by energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) and estimated that all the elements like Mg, Ti and O are present in appropiate atomic as well as weight percentage . Valency state and surface oxidation state of synthesized catalyst was analysed by X-ray photo electron spectroscopy (XPS) and illustrated in Fig. (4) . The respective spectrum at various binding energies indicates the presence of Mg, Ti and O elements in synthesized catalyst. The characteristics peaks at 457.2 eV, 464.7 eV correspond to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Ti and confirm +4 oxidation state of Ti in MgTiO3 catalyst [44]. The peak having binding energy at 1304 eV is attributed to 1 s spectra of Mg2+ species indicating that Mg is present at +2 oxidation state. In XPS spectrum of oxygen there are several characteristics peaks were found at different binding energies [45,46]. Sublattice oxygen with metal atoms in mixed oxide, absorbed oxygen species, and water molecules bound to catalysts are attributed to the peaks at binding energies of 530.12 eV, 532.16 eV, and 529.76 eV, respectively. Hence XPS spectrum determines the pureness of the MgTiO3 catalyst as specified. N2 adsorption-desorption curves of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 5 . It is observed from the plot that the catalyst exhibits type II hysteresis loops as per IUPAC classification with mesoporous structure. The specific surface area of MgTiO3 perovskite is 27.58 m2/g with pore diameter 36 nm. Since the catalyst having high surface area responsible for enhancing the activity of transesterification reaction of glycerol. The plot in Fig. 6 shows the results of Raman spectroscopy, which is one of the most important techniques for identifying variations in local symmetry for the surface structure. The synthesized MgTiO3 perovskite shows Raman spectrum in the range of 150 to 700 cm−1. The synthesized perovskite mainly shows four Raman active modes at 142, 395, 512 and 638 cm−1 which correspond to Ag, Eg, Ag and Eg symmetry respectively [44]. There are also some additional peaks at 142.3 and 203 cm−1 might be due to unreacted starting precursors [47–49]. The basic strength and total basicity of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst was studied by Hammett indicator titration method and found that basic strength of designed perovskite lies in the range of 15< H_< 18.6. Indicators like 2,4-dinitroaniline (H_ =15.6), phenolphthalein (H_ =9.6), bromothymol blue (H_= 7.8), 4 nitroaniline (H_ = 15.4) were used for determination of basic strength of synthesized catalyst. Total basicity of MgTiO3 was relatively high about 11.46 mmolg−1 which reflects the outstanding performance in transesterification reaction of glycerol. 3.1 Influence of reaction parameters The catalyst loading percentage had a significant impact on glycerol transesterification, as shown in Fig. 7 . (a). The increase in glycerol conversion from 38 to 93.7% with an increase in catalyst loading from 3 to 12 wt.% could be related to an increase in the number of active sites. At 12 wt.% catalyst in relation to the amount of glycerol employed in the process, the maximum conversion of glycerol was achieved. As the concentration of catalyst increased over 12 wt% loading, catalytic activity reduced. This might be due to the resistance of mass transfer in the liquid-solid phase system [18,50]. The molar ratio of DMC to glycerol, which is one of the reaction factors impacting glycerol transesterification, was also investigated and displayed in Fig. 7(b). The conversion percentage of glycerol increased from 41.4 to 93.7% as the molar ratio of Gly-to DMC was raised from 1:1 to 1:6. The selectivity of glycerol carbonate was 90.2% at a 1:6 molar ratio of gly to DMC. The selectivity of glycerol carbonate decreased when the molar ratio of gly to DMC went above 1:6, which could be attributed to a solubility impact due to immiscibility of glycerol and DMC at high concentrations [23,51]. The effect of reaction temperature to trans esterify glycerol was investigated and displayed in Fig. 7. (c) The plot shows that increasing temperature from 30° to 90 °C the selectivity of glycerol carbonate reached up to 90.2%. Above 90 °C there was no increase in conversion of glycerol. The reason behind decrease in selectivity of glycerol carbonate was explored and it might be due to reduction in viscosity of the reaction mixture at high temperature [30,52], another factor is that above 90 °C there was loss of DMC by evaporation as the boiling temperature of DMC closes to 90 °C . Transesterification reaction is also affected by time duration and the plot is given in Fig. 7(d). The selectivity of glycerol carbonate was increased from 32% to 88.2% with increase in reaction time from 30 min to 180 min. After 3 h the efficacy was reduced indicating the optimum time for highest selectivity of GLC. The drop in selectivity percentage could be related to product side reactions, such as the synthesis of glycidol as after a certain time period the reaction goes forward glycidol selectivity [9,53] . 3.2 Reusability study of MgTiO3 catalyst The recyclability of synthesized MgTiO3 perovskite was also studied and represented in Fig. 8 . From the plot it was observed that the efficacy of the catalyst remained constant up to sixth cycle with 86% glycerol carbonate selectivity. The conversion as well as selectivity of glycerol and glycerol carbonate reduced to 46 and 38.9% respectively after six times run of catalyst. The reason behind reduction of glycerol conversion was investigated by X-ray diffraction and SEM-EDX analysis. The SEM-image revealed that the particle size of MgTiO3 perovskite after sixth cycle was much larger than the fresh catalyst indicating the decrease in active surface area of MgTiO3 catalyst. The elemental composition of sixth MgTiO3 catalyst reflected the loss of atomic weight percentage of catalyst which might be due to leaching of active metals in the reaction mixture. Similarly, from X-ray diffraction pattern of sixth reused catalyst it was observed that there were many extra peaks are present indicating change in different phases. The intensity of peaks were decreased and many other peaks were present in the synthesized catalyst after sixth cycle of reaction. There are many diffraction peaks of MgCO3 such as 2θ = 24.72°, 29.04°, 34.44°, 51.87° corresponding miller indices (210), (211), (412) and (511) were present in sixth reused catalyst due to trapping of atmospheric CO2 by the catalyst. Besides these there are other peaks at 2θ = 31.05°, 43.78° having miller indices value (221), (422) correspond to MgTi2O5 phase (JCPDS file- 70–2112) and the diffraction peaks like 66.48° (503), 74.48°(700) are due to creation of another phase of titanium with carbon i.e. TiC-C composite which matched with JCPDS file 32–1387. 3.3 Comparative study of designed mgtio3 catalyst with other reported catalyst The comparative study of catalytic activity of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst in transesterification reaction of glycerol with previously used catalyst is given in Table 1 . It is observed that uncalcined Mg-Al catalyst in transesterification of glycerol provided 75% conversion where as nickel hydrotalcite [38] shows 56% glycerol carbonate yield. Similarly, catalyst like LiCl/CaO [57] provided 87.3% yield with five times recyclability. Catalyst like Ti-SBA15 [52] provided very low yield percentage of 66.45 after three times recyclability. Mg/Zr/Sr [26] mixed oxides required high DMC to glycerol molar ratio (5:1) as well as very loading percentage of catalyst i.e., 15 wt.% loading for providing 92% conversion of glycerol. Many other catalysts like NaOH/γ-Al2O3 [27], CaO-Al2O3 [28], CaO-MgO [54], K2CO3/MgO [55], Mg/La [56] although provided very good conversion of glycerol but the reusability of these catalysts towards transesterification of glycerol were very poor due to leaching of metal atoms after a certain time in reaction process. Many catalysts like Mg/Al hydrotalcites/hydroxyapatite, Mg/Al hydrotalcite supported on α-Al2O3 uses solvents like methanol, DMSO, DMF in transesterification reaction of glycerol whereas the transesterification of glycerol in presence of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst possesses solvent free reaction condition. Taking all these in account the designed MgTiO3 is one of the suitable as well as comparable catalyst with other reported catalyst for transesterification of glycerol. It is one of the cheaper and efficient catalyst achieving very good selectivity towards glycerol carbonate. 4 Conclusion Mg based perovskite can be efficiently used for transesterification of glycerol providing 93% conversion. Greener route was adopted for synthesis of MgTiO3 catalyst and the catalyst was successfully designed. Several characterizations techniques like XRD, SEM, Raman and XPS spectra were also confirmed the complete formation of MgTiO3 catalyst. High surface area and strong basicity of synthesized MgTiO3 catalyst are mainly responsible for providing 90.2% selectivity of glycerol carbonate. High crystallinity, uniform particle size distribution improved the catalytic performance of transesterification of glycerol. Considering the catalytic potential, physico-chemical properties, it suggests that MgTiO3 catalyst is greener promising catalyst and can be utilized in industrial sector for synthesis of glycerol carbonate. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol has gained major research attention because of its wide application in lithium-ion battery and pharmaceutical companies. Current study summarises the catalytic transformation of glycerol-to-glycerol carbonate using MgTiO3 perovskite catalyst. Here,we have reported the synthesis of MgTiO3 catalyst by simple co-precipitation route and investigated the catalytic activity in transesterification of glycerol. The physico-chemical properties of MgTiO3 catalyst was successfully studied by XRD, SEM-EDX, XPS, Raman spectra, BET-surface area and TGA analysis. The designed catalyst possesses high catalytic efficiency and stability in transesterification reaction of glycerol. Depending upon its surface area and basicity many experiments were performed and observed that under optimized condition i.e., 12 wt.% catalyst loading, 6:1 molar ratio of DMC to glycerol, 90 °C and at 180 min highest conversion of glycerol 93% and 88% selectivity of glycerol carbonate was achieved. The reusability study also revealed that MgTiO3 perovskite is highly efficient and stable catalyst to trans esterify glycerol with 88% selectivity towards glycerol carbonate up to sixth cycle.
coredata.dc:title: An accelerated route for synthesis of Glycerol carbonate using MgTiO3 perovskite as greener and cheaper catalyst
